sections.summary: This opening range identifies the Scripture as a guide and a reminder for believers to follow divine **revelation** rather than other masters. It warns of the destruction of previous towns for their **wrongdoing** and establishes that on the Day of Judgment, deeds will be weighed on a just **Scale** to determine success or loss.

sections.theme: The Fall of Adam and Satan’s Vow
sections.summary: These verses recount the creation of humanity and **Satan’s** refusal to prostrate due to **arrogance** over his origin from fire. Following his expulsion, Satan vowed to waylay humans from the **straight path**, leading to the deception of Adam and Eve in the Garden and their subsequent descent to earth as enemies after their **repentance** [112–113].

Allah addresses the Children of Adam, urging them to prioritize the **clothing of piety** and to wear proper **adornment** at every place of worship [113–114]. It prohibits **immoralities**, unjustified aggression, and **shirk** (associating others with Allah), while reminding humanity that every nation has a fixed **term** [113–114].

This section details the dialogue between the inhabitants of **Paradise** and the **Fire**, highlighting the regret of those who rejected divine signs [114–115]. It introduces the men of the **Elevations (Al-A'raf)**, who recognize both groups by their marks and hope for mercy despite not yet entering the Garden [115–116].

Allah is identified as the Lord who created the universe in six days and settled over the **Throne**, regulating the sun, moon, and stars by His command. Believers are exhorted to call upon Him with **fear and hope**, utilizing the revival of dead land through rain as a sign of the **Resurrection** [116–117].

A series of historical accounts features prophets such as **Noah, Hud, Saleh, Lot, and Shuaib**, each warning their respective communities against **idolatry** and social injustice [117–120]. These narratives illustrate a recurring pattern where the arrogant elite reject the **truth**, leading to their utter destruction by floods, quakes, or storms [117–120].

The text reflects on how nations were tested with **adversity** to encourage humility and **prosperity** to test their gratitude. It concludes that the hearts of disbelievers become **sealed** because they disregard the divine plan and remain untrue to their covenants [120–121].

Moses is sent with clear **miracles**, such as his staff and white hand, to confront the tyranny of **Pharaoh** and the magicians [121–122]. Despite the magicians' submission, Pharaoh persisted in disbelief even as Egypt was afflicted with **plagues** of locusts, lice, frogs, and blood, eventually resulting in the drowning of the oppressors [121–123].

sections.theme: The Covenant and the Golden Calf
sections.summary: After crossing the sea, the Children of Israel lapsed into **idolatry** by worshiping a golden calf in Moses’ absence [123–125]. Moses sought **forgiveness** for his people and pleaded for mercy during his appointment with Allah, where the divine glory was manifested to the mountain [124–125].

sections.theme: The Mission of the Unlettered Prophet
sections.summary: These verses describe the **Unlettered Prophet (Muhammad)**, whose coming is recorded in the **Torah and Gospel**. He is sent as a universal messenger to all mankind to enjoin virtue, prohibit evil, and release humanity from their spiritual **shackles**.

The text reviews the history of the Children of Israel, including the gushing of twelve springs and the test of the **Sabbath** [126–127]. It details how those who violated divine limits were transformed into **apes**, serving as a lesson for those who uphold the Scripture [126–127].

sections.theme: The Primordial Covenant and Divine Names
sections.summary: The narrative recounts the **Primordial Covenant** where all descendants of Adam testified to Allah’s Lordship. It warns against those who detach from divine signs to follow their desires and emphasizes that to Allah belong the **Most Beautiful Names**.

sections.theme: Rejection of Guidance and Helpless Idols
sections.summary: Those who deny the revelations are led gradually to ruin, while the helplessness of **idols** is exposed through their inability to create or provide help [129–130]. It clarifies that knowledge of the **Hour** rests solely with Allah and that the Messenger is only a warner and a herald of good news [129–130].

The surah concludes with commands to practice **tolerance**, seek refuge from Satan, and remember Allah humbly and fearfully [130–131]. It enjoins the believers to listen with silence when the **Quran** is recited so they may receive mercy and be among those who **prostrate** to their Lord [130–131].
